facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 26 and 162 of 1969 are appeals by certificates from the judgment and order dated October 13, 14 and 16, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 98 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 26 and 162 of 1969. Appeals by certificates from the judgment and order dated October 13, 14 and 16, 1967 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 98 of 1962.

facts.text: A partnership firm comprising of some of the members of the Sassoon family was carrying on business under the name and style of E. D. Sassoon Co. for a number of years prior to 1920 at Bombay, Calcutta, Karachi, Hongkong, Shanghai, London, Manchester, Basra and the Persian Gulf.

anchor.surface_text: A partnership firm  hereinafter referred to as the firm  companyprising of some of the members of the Sassoon family was carrying on business under the name and style of E. D. Sassoon Co. for a number of years prior to 1920 at Bombay, Calcutta, Karachi, Hongkong, Shanghai, London, Manchester, Basra and the Persian Gulf.

facts.text: The business carried on by the firm was that of bankers, commission agent, agents of joint stock companies, dealers in shares and securities, foreign exchange etc.

anchor.surface_text: The business which it was carrying on was that of the bankers, companymission agent, agents of joint stock companypanies, dealers in shares and securities, foreign exchange etc.

facts.text: In the accounting year 1919 the firm incurred net loss of Rs. 12,37,413-12-2.

anchor.surface_text: In the accounting year 1919 the firm incurred net loss of Rs. 12,37,41312-2 but in 1920 it seems to have made large profits mostly in London Exchange Account.

facts.text: In 1920 the firm made large profits mostly in London Exchange Account and claimed depreciation in shares and securities amounting to Rs. 9,26,730-5-8.

anchor.surface_text: but in 1920 it seems to have made large profits mostly in London Exchange Account. It however claimed depreciation in shares and securities amounting to Rs. 9,26,730-5-8 shown under the head depreciation in shares and securities.

facts.text: On 8th September 1920 Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd. was incorporated in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: On 8th September 1920 and 4th December 1920 two companypanies were incorporated in Bombay the former was known as the Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd. and the latter as E. D. Sassoon Co. Ltd.  hereinafter called the assessee companypany .

facts.text: On 4th December 1920 E. D. Sassoon Co. Ltd. (assessee company) was incorporated in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: On 8th September 1920 and 4th December 1920 two companypanies were incorporated in Bombay the former was known as the Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd. and the latter as E. D. Sassoon Co. Ltd.  hereinafter called the assessee companypany .

facts.text: By the end of December 1920, B.T.C. had investments in shares and securities to the extent of Rs. 3,23,78,494/-

anchor.surface_text: This companypany  B.T.C.  had by the end of December 1920 investments in shares and securities to the extent of Rs. 3,23,78,494/-. By the end of 1921 investments in shares and securities had risen to Rs. 4,31,32,212/-

facts.text: The assessee company was incorporated with object to acquire and take over as a going concern the business carried on at various places by the firm and its assets and liabilities.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany was incorporated with several objects one of which was To acquire and take over as a going companycern the business number carried on at Bombay, Calcutta, Karachi, Hongkong, Shanghai, London, Manchester, Basra and Bagdad and all or any of the assets and liabilities of the proprietors of that business

facts.text: On June 30, 1961 the agreement referred to was finally executed by the assessee company. [Note: likely 1921 per context]

anchor.surface_text: On June 30, 1961 the agreement referred to was finally executed by the assessee companypany. The said agreement provided inter alia for purchase of the business of the said firm and its assets including shares, and debentures

facts.text: Pursuant to the agreement, the company took over the business of the firm and purchased shares and securities worth Rs. 1,93,79,521-3-1 at market value as on 31st December 1920.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that pursuant to the said agreement the companypany took over the business of the said firm and also purchased shares and securities worth Rs. 1,93,79,521-3-1 at market value as on 31st December 1920.

facts.text: The assessee company purchased between 1st January 1921 to 31st January 1921 from the market further shares and securities worth Rs. 4,28,05,627 in the ordinary course of its business.

anchor.surface_text: It further purchased between 1st January 1921 to 31st January 1921 from the market further shares and securities worth Rs. 4,28,05,627 in the ordinary companyrse of its business.

facts.text: Supreme Court confirms assessee entitled to relief under section 25(3).

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that in any view of the matter the assessee companypany was entitled to relief under section 25 3 , as such, the judgement of the High Court has to be companyfirmed.

In the year of assessment 1949-50 the assessee company discontinued its business and claimed exemption on Rs. 33,40,057 under S. 25(3) of the Act. This claim was rejected by the Income-tax Officer on the ground (1) that in the year 1921 the assessee claimed and obtained a deduction in respect of appreciation in shares and securities amounting to Rs. 9,26,708/- and (2) it had discontinued one of the businesses which the firm was doing namely dealing in stocks and shares.

concepts.unlisted_description: Relief from tax on discontinuance of business previously charged under 1918 Act

anchor.surface_text: WHETHER on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the assessee company is entitled to claim exemption under Section 25(3) of the Act?

concepts.unlisted_description: Relief from tax on discontinuance of business previously charged under 1918 Act

anchor.surface_text: Sub-s. (3) of s. 25 under which the relief is being claimed is, as follows - Where any business, profession or vocation on which tax was at any time charged under the provisions of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1918 (VII of 1918), is discontinued, then, unless there has been a succession by virtue of which the provisions of sub-section (4) have been rendered applicable no tax shall be payable in respect of the income, profits and gains of the period between the end of the previous year and the date of such discontinuance, and the assessee may further claim that the income, profits and gains of the previous year shall be deemed to have been the income, profits and gains of the said period.

concepts.interpretation: Enacted to mitigate hardship of double taxation arising from shift to previous year basis in 1922 Act; requires three conditions: (i) business taxed at any time under 1918 Act, (ii) no succession under sub-s.(4) post 1.4.1939, (iii) complete discontinuance/cessation of business.

anchor.surface_text: But there is no reason to restrict the condition of the applicability of the exemption only to income on which the tax was payable under the head profit and gains of business, profession or vocation. The legislature has made no such express reservation and there is no warrant for reading into subsection (3) it may be noticed does not refer to chargeability of income to tax under a particular head as a condition of obtaining the benefit of the exemption. . . . . But the exemption under section 25(3) is general, it is not restricted to income chargeable under section 10 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Three conditions for s.25(3): (1) business taxed under 1918 at any time; (2) no succession post 1.4.1939; (3) complete discontinuance

anchor.surface_text: An assessee to obtain relief under the above sub-section has to satisfy three conditions. Firstly, that the business, profession ,or vocation must be one on which tax was at any time charged under the 1918 Act. Secondly, the case must be one where there has not been a succession after the 1st April, 1939 attracting the application of sub-s. (4). Thirdly, the business must be discontinued, such discontinuance amounting to a complete cessation of business and not merely a succession or change of owner-ship.

arguments.claim: Purpose of s.25(3) to avoid double taxation from change to previous year basis

anchor.surface_text: This provision has been enacted to give relief to a tax payer upon whom extra burden had been imposed due to a change in the basis of assessment as a result of the Act of 1922. Under the 1918 Act the tax liability was imposed on the income accruing or arising in the year of assessment while under the 1922 Act the liability was in respect of income accruing or arising in the previous year.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ly to give relief to a tax payer who but for it would in the aggregate be charged with tax once in r

holdings.text: The assessee company was entitled to relief under section 25(3) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that in any view of the matter the assessee companypany was entitled to relief under section 25 3 , as such, the judgement of the High Court has to be companyfirmed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All three conditions satisfied: business previously taxed under 1918 Act, no barring succession, complete discontinuance on liquidation; confirms High Court judgment.

holdings.text: To obtain relief under s.25(3), assessee must satisfy three conditions: (1) business taxed at any time under 1918 Act; (2) no succession after 1.4.1939 under s.25(4); (3) complete cessation of business on discontinuance.

anchor.surface_text: An assessee to obtain relief under the above sub-section has to satisfy three companyditions. Firstly, that the business, profession ,or vocation must be one on which tax was at any time charged under the 1918 Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.25(3); all conditions fulfilled here as firm assessed under 1918 Act, assessee successor pre-1939, liquidation as cessation.

holdings.text: Liquidation of the assessee company on 28th December 1948 constituted discontinuance of business for s.25(3).

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute in this case that the, assessee companypany had discontinued its business from the 28th December 1948 when it went into liquidation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No dispute; complete cessation, not mere succession or change of ownership.

holdings.text: Exemption under s.25(3) is general and not restricted to income chargeable under the head 'Profits and gains of business, profession or vocation' (s.10).

anchor.surface_text: But there is no reason to restrict the condition of the applicability of the exemption only to income on which the tax was payable under the head profit and gains of business, profession or vocation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: no express reservation in s.25(3); follows Chugandas Co. and O.R.M. SP. SV. Firm; applies even if share dealing disputed, as other firm businesses continued then discontinued.

holdings.text: The judgment of the Bombay High Court is confirmed in its entirety.

anchor.surface_text: the assessee companypany was entitled to relief under section 25 3 , as such, the judgement of the High Court has to be companyfirmed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entitlement to s.25(3) relief dispositive; no arguments on other questions (i2-i5); upholds HC answers: i2 against assessee, i3-i5 for assessee.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. P.E. Polson 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. P.E. Polson 1 which was also referred to by Patanjali Sastri, J. in Executors of Estate of Dubash v. Commissioner of Income-tax  2   the Privy Council has pointed out that the purpose and ,effect of sub-section 3 was clearly to give relief to a tax payer who but for it would in the aggregate be charged with tax once in respect of every years income and twice in respect of one years income.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. P.E. Polson
precedents.cited_proposition: purpose and effect of sub-section 3 was clearly to give relief to a tax payer who but for it would in the aggregate be charged with tax once in respect of every years income and twice in respect of one years income

precedents.citation: Executors of Estate of Dubash v. Commissioner of Income-tax  2

anchor.surface_text: Executors of Estate of Dubash v. Commissioner of Income-tax  2   the Privy Council has pointed out that the purpose and ,effect of sub-section 3 was clearly to give relief to a tax payer who but for it would in the aggregate be charged with tax once in respect of every years income and twice in respect of one years income. There is no dispute in this case that the, assessee company had discontinued its business from the 28th December 1948 when it went into liquidation.

precedents.case_name: Executors of Estate of Dubash v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: reference to Polson case by Patanjali Sastri J. regarding purpose of s.25(3)

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City-1 v. Chugandas Co. 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City-1 v. Chugandas Co. 1  Shah, J., after noticing that what is to be regarded as income, profits and gains of business, profession or vocation within the meaning of section 25 3  for which exemption may be obtained on discontinuance had given rise to difficulties, observed at page 22 -- Now clause  3  of section 25 expressly provides that income of a business, profession or vocation which was charged at any time under Act 7 of 1918 to tax is. on discontinuance of that business, profession or vocation, exempt from liability to tax under Act II of 1922 for the period between the end of the previous year and the date of such discontinuance

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City-1 v. Chugandas & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: exemption under section 25(3) is general and not restricted to income chargeable under section 10 or a particular head; applies to any business charged under 1918 Act
precedents.cited_holding: the exemption under section 25(3) is general, it is not restricted to income chargeable under section 10 of the Act

precedents.citation: O. R M. SP. SV. Firm v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2

anchor.surface_text: O. R M. SP. SV. Firm v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2 . It appears to us that in any view of the matter the assessee company was entitled to relief under section 25 3 , as such, the judgement of the High Court has to be confirmed.

precedents.case_name: O. R. M. SP. SV. Firm v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: followed Chugandas on general applicability of exemption under s.25(3)

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that in any view of the matter the assessee companypany was entitled to relief under section 25 3 , as such, the judgement of the High Court has to be confirmed.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court judgment confirmed; assessee entitled to relief/exemption under Section 25(3) of the Income-tax Act, 1922
